source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Minuria
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Minuria. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves linear, c. 1 mm wide, sometimes toothed or narrowly lobed; stems and peduncles sparsely to densely pubescent (rarely quite glabrous), margins and/or apices of outer involucral bracts shortly ciliate or fimbriate; disc cypselas with pappus of barbellate bristles surrounded by a distinctly shorter series of bristles or scales
Leaves narrow-lanceolate to -oblanceolate, 2–3 mm wide, entire; stems, peduncles and outer involucral bracts glabrous; disc cypselas with pappus of more or less uni- form barbellate bristles only

Stems sparsely pubescent with short hairs only or glabrescent; leaves acute, entire (very rarely subapically toothed); pappus of disc cypselas with outer shorter series of bristles or scales more than one-quarter as long as longer bristles

Young stems densely white-cottony (sometimes becoming glabrous with age); leaves obtuse, often toothed or shortly lobed near apex; pappus of disc cypselas with shorter series of bristles less than one-quarter as long as longer bristles

Inner involucral bracts broadest at or below the middle, to 0.8 mm wide, without broad membranous margins or margins very narrow; mature ray cypselas sparsely pubescent, with pappus 6.5–9.5 mm long; subshrub to c. 60 cm high

Inner involucral bracts broadest above the middle, 1 mm wide or more, with broad membranous margins; mature ray cypselas densely silky-pubescent, with pappus 2.5–5 mm long; decumbent to weakly erect herb to c. 30 cm high
